review.title: Decision Tree Classification on Outsourced Data
review.abstract: This paper proposes a client-server decision tree learning method for outsourced private data. The privacy model is anatomization/fragmentation: the server sees data values, but the link between sensitive and identifying information is encrypted with a key known only to clients. Clients have limited processing and storage capability. Both sensitive and identifying information thus are stored on the server. The approach presented also retains most processing at the server, and client-side processing is amortized over predictions made by the clients. Experiments on various datasets show that the method produces decision trees approaching the accuracy of a non-private decision tree, while substantially reducing the client's computing resource requirements.

sections.heading: 1.1 Related Work
sections.text: There are studies on how to mine anonymized data. Fung et al. [9] specify a top-down method for specializing in mining (TDS) for anonymization, so that the anonymized data allow precise decision trees. Chui et al. [3] and Leung et al. [18], however, address the common item set mining problem. Ngai et al. suggests a clustering algorithm that treats the anonymized data as uncertain information [26]. Kriegel et al. suggest a hierarchical cluster method that uses unclear objects [17]. Xiao et al. discusses the problem of distance calculation for unsafe objects [31]. The classification of Nearest Neighbor with generalized data is examined by Martin [22]. Zhang et al. Studies Naive Baye use partially specified data [33]. Dowd et al. examines decision tree classifiers with random substitutions [7].

sections.heading: 1.2 Contributions
sections.text: The model of [25] would allow a client to construct an exact decision tree by downloading the identifier and sensitive tables of a dataset (or a data table), decrypting the join key, and connecting the identifying and sensitive information (rebuilding the original dataset); the rest of this paper will use the terms dataset and data table interchangeably; the goal of this paper is to reduce the client's resource requirements by doing as much work as possible on the server; the challenge is that the server must not know exact mappings between identifying and sensitive information (and the server cannot know these mappings without background knowledge due to the L-diversity of the anatomization scheme); we assume that the class attribute is not the sensitive attribute, as effective learning this at the server implies a de facto violation of l-diversity.

sections.heading: 2. DEFINITIONS AND PREDICTION TASK
sections.text: We give a set of definitions that are necessary to explain our work, and use them to define the prediction task for anatomized data.

sections.heading: 3. ANATOMIZATION DECISION TREES
sections.text: We examine three possible approaches to building decision trees from anatomized data in the client-server database model by Nergiz et al. We refer to this family of decision trees as anatomization decision trees because they are all composed of anatomized data. Each approach differs depending on how IT and ST tables are used. In the discussion of anatomization decision trees, it is assumed that algorithms that require encryption use symmetrical key encryption AES-128. We first discuss two basic approaches: pure client-side learning and pure server-side learning. Section 3.2 explains the collaborative learning of decision trees. Finally, we compare collaborative learning with the basics in Section 3.3.

sections.heading: 3.3 Cost Discussion
sections.text: It is difficult to estimate a practical average cost saving for collaborative decision-tree learning, as it depends not only on the data, but also on the cost of storage, processing and communication resources of the customer. If the identifying attributes are bad predictors, the base decision tree will be complex. However, a complex decision-tree model means that the cost per sub-tree will be small, although the total cost (amortized over many predictions) is high. If the identifying attributes are good predictors, the base decision tree will be easy to achieve a good prediction. However, small leaves mean that the cost per sub-tree will be small, although the total cost (amortized over many predictions) is high. If the identifying attributes are good predictors, the base decision tree will yield fewer splits, but larger leaves. This increases the cost of the initial prediction, but also increases the likelihood that a decision will be made in the future.

sections.heading: 4. EXPERIMENTS

sections.heading: 5. CONCLUSION
sections.text: This paper proposes a method for learning decision trees for outsourced data in an anatomization scheme. To accomplish this prediction task, a real prediction task is defined: Collaborative Decision Tree Learning (cdtl), which uses cloud database server (CDBS) and client, is investigated. Cdtl is proven to preserve the privacy of the data provider. Cdtl is tested on different sets of data and the results show that relatively accurate decision trees can be built while significantly reducing the customer's learning and inference costs. The next challenge is to expand this work in a new framework so that no client processing takes place while precise decision trees are learned. Another direction is to observe how the collaborative decision tree learning algorithm performs compared to recent differential decision trees.
